docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican candidate for the United States Senate in South Carolina, Representative Jim DeMint, left, apologized for saying, when questioned about a comment that gays should not work in public schools, that unwed pregnant women should likewise be banned. Mr. DeMint said he was speaking as a parent who wants the best for children when he made the remark on Tuesday. ''I clearly said something as a dad that I just shouldn't have said,'' said Mr. DeMint, a father of four. ''And I apologize.'' While responding to questions about the earlier comment on gay teachers, Mr. DeMint told The Aiken Standard, ''I would have given the same answer when asked if a single woman who was pregnant and living with her boyfriend should be hired to teach my third-grade children.'' His campaign manager, Terry Sullivan, said he did not mean to offend anyone with either comment. Mr. DeMint, a three-term congressman, was raised by a single mother.

headline.main: SPEAKING AS A FATHER, NOT A SON
headline.kicker: THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING -- THE STATES

docs.lead_paragraph: When a baby's shoulder blocks passage into the birth canal, many obstetricians perform an episiotomy, in the belief that the incision, which widens the vagina, will lead to fewer fetal injuries. But according to a study released yesterday, episiotomies actually cause more injuries than they prevent.

headline.main: Clearing the Way for Baby, Safely

docs.abstract: Dr Edith D Gurewitsch, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine researcher, leads study that shows manual manipulation of fetus when shoulder dystocia occurs is safer on baby and mother than use of episiotomy to enlarge birth canal; only 35 percent of babies suffer arm injuries when obstetrician uses manual manipulation rather than 60 percent of babies with reported injuries when delivered using episiotomy (S)
docs.snippet: According to a new study, episiotomies actually cause more injuries than they prevent.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite laws that ban so-called drive-by deliveries, many newborns come home from the hospital within a day or two of birth. Some quickly return, most often because of jaundice or dehydration. But a study released yesterday found that home visits by nurses during the first 10 days of life virtually did away with such return trips.
docs.abstract: Dr Ian M Paul of Pennsylvania State University leads study on impact of home visits by nurses in first 10 days after newborn baby leaves hospital; study, published in journal Pediatrics, finds significant drop in number of newborns returning to hospital in that time period due to complications, if nurse visits home; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A recent study found that home visits by nurses during the first 10 days of life virtually did away with return hospital trips by babies.

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time in a generation, New York State has had sustained declines in out-of-wedlock births, state officials said yesterday. Indeed, from 1999 to 2002, New York experienced the greatest numerical reduction in births to unwed mothers of any state in the country. In New York, births to unwed mothers of all ages dropped from 95,033 in 2000 to 90,746 in 2001 and to 89,840 in 2002, the most recent years for which data was available. They were the first two years of consecutive declines in the state since 1974, officials said. Even measured as a percentage of population, the pace of the drop, 2.4 percent, was second only to that of the District of Columbia, federal officials said.

headline.main: It's a Trend: Births Out of Wedlock Are Falling Statewide

docs.abstract: New York State has sustained declines in out-of-wedlock births for first time in generation; state officials say from 1999 to 2002, New York experienced greatest numerical reduction in births to unwed mothers of any state in US; births to unwed mothers of all ages in state dropped from 95,033 in 2000 to 90,746 in 2001 and to 89,840 in 2002; sociologists and policy makers disagree about causes of decline; New York receives $25 million grant from Health and Human Services Dept because of decrease (M)
docs.snippet: For the first time in a generation, New York State has had sustained declines in out-of-wedlock births.

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York Musical Theater Festival is finishing up its three-week showcase on Sunday after presenting 31 shows. Information about times and venues: www.nymf.org. Theater Three Trailer trash may be an easy target, but Armadillo Acres trailer trash is distinctive. There's Lin (Marya Grandy), named Linoleum because she was born on the kitchen floor, whose husband is on death row. There's Pickles (Amanda Ryan Paige), who's 17 and in a perpetual state of hysterical pregnancy. And there's Betty (Robin Baxter), the mobile home mama/manager whose husband died and left her the keys. When we meet the ladies of Armadillo Acres they're tanning themselves on lawn chairs with metal sun reflectors out in front of a brilliant suggestion of mobile homes. These gals are Thornton Wilder's Stage Manager in triplicate, but a whole lot wilder, dabbling throughout the two-act spectacle in erotic dancing, TV show confessionals, disco, sleuthing and flan.
docs.abstract: Camille Sweeney reviews The Great American Trailer Park Musical, with music and lyrics by David Nehls, book by Betsy Kelso and starring Marya Grandy, Amanda Ryan Paige and Robin Baxter (M)
